data.title: Non-existent pages on wiki
data.body:
I couldn't help but notice:

~~Creating a 3D game~~
~~Exporting for HTML5 (using asm.js)~~
~~Exporting for consoles (PS3, PSVita, etc)~~

Are such things currently possible, although there's no wiki page for them? If so, this game engine is exactly what I'm looking for.

data.title: Handle breakpoint toggling at run time
data.body: It is not currently possible to deactivate a breakpoint at runtime once it has been triggered

data.title: Parent/child rendering order
data.body:
Hi, I have seen that creating a object and then his son, the son renders me over the father.
example:
    var button = Sprite.new()
    button.set_texture(load("res://button.png"))
    button.set_pos(pos)
    add_child(button)
    var deco = Sprite.new()
    deco.set_texture(load("res://deco.png"))
    deco.set_pos(Vector2(0,0))
    button.add_child(deco)

In this example, "deco" is drawn over the button, and as a son, I have no way to change it.
But if this same amount from the editor button is rendered over the deco

do scons bin/godot and run

Then in menu create new project or import demo, then do edit it.

Strace on binary shows SIGSEGVs.
any ideas?

data.body:
Hey, there. So I'm having a crash when I attempt to add a scene as a child of a node through code (instancing the scene and then adding it as a child).

https://copy.com/mGhEOkNhTHEN1dC3

EDIT: Oh, to recreate the crash, just play the currently edited scene. I thought this had something to do with not having a main scene, but that doesn't seem to be the case. Oh, well.

I'm running:

Windows 7 64-bit
4GB RAM
AMD Radeon HD 7750
Godot Win 32-bit 1.0 Development version from the homepage, 5/29/14

data.title: PacketPeer.get_var(): add a way to check for available var without calling get_var or remove error from console
data.body:
```
ERROR: get_packet: Condition ' remaining<4 ' is true. returned: ERR_UNAVAILABLE
   At: core/io/packet_peer.cpp:181.
```

i get this in console every time i check get_var for new incoming variables and it returns no data...

If you are not sending data all the time, and check it inside _process(), the output is too big it clutters the console

maybe add a is_var() to check if theres a var before calling get_var

data.title: Sprite3D doesn't update frame on changing property
data.body:
Hey, there. I was testing out the new Sprite3D node, and it seems that animations on the node don't update every frame. For example, changing the frame property only updates the mesh if you alter some property of the node, like change its centered property or region property. Animations don't seem to work (though I'm not sure if I'm running them properly), I'm guessing because I'm not altering any property of the mesh.

To reproduce this, just make a Sprite3D node with a texture, and try to step through the frames using the frame property. You'll see the node doesn't update.

Thanks for reading!

data.title: Added new API to RemoteTransform2D (ability to ignore pos/rot/scale and track backwards)
data.body:
Closes okamstudio/godot#265

Track backwards means that the RemoteTransform2D node gets transformed instead (it's now possible to transform multiple nodes by just transforming one)

data.title: Crash On Making Convex Collision Mesh Out of Terrain
data.body:
Hey, there. I've found a crash on attempting to create a convex physics collision mesh out of a hilly terrain object. I thought it was because the terrain is not convex, but the crash doesn't seem to occur on a (what I think was) simpler concave mesh.

In any case, to reproduce, download and open the attached scene file, click on the Plane (terrain) mesh, and select "Create Convex Collision" from the Inspector's "gear" options menu. Godot will then crash. Here's the link:

https://copy.com/7ooRIxKja7wY

If this is a matter of it being an "intended bug" because I'm using it incorrectly, then a check to find concave polygons and abort before a crash would probably be a good idea. Or perhaps it could be automatic, and go with a trimesh collision mesh if there are concave lines, and a convex mesh otherwise (though, informing the developer might be a good idea).

I have:

AMD Athlon II X2 250 3.0 GHZ Processor
Windows 7 64-bit
4GB RAM
AMD Radeon HD 7750
Godot Win 32-bit 1.0 Development version from the homepage, 5/29/14

Anyway, thanks a lot for reading!

data.title: report somehow server failing to open a port
data.body:
launch twice (at the same time) this code to reproduce the issue:

```
    extends Node2D

    # member variables here, example:
    # var a=2
    # var b="textvar"
    var server

    func _ready():
       server = TCP_Server.new()
       var con = server.listen(9955)
       print("con ",con)
       if !con:
          print("Server is up and running")
       else:
          print("unable to create server")

       set_process(true)

    func _process(dt):
       if(server):
          pass

```

output:

```
********* listening on port 9955
OK! 30
con 0
Server is up and running

********* listening on port 9955
OK! 17
con 0
Server is up and running
CLOSING CONNECTION
```

checking the ports... the port is owned by the first process and the second clearly failed...

forum reference: http://www.godotengine.org/forum/viewtopic.php?f=11&t=648&p=2849

I know xml does not enforce any order... thats why maybe changing to other format or other  more drastic solution is due.

Thing is that is hard to keep projects under source control with more than one contributor if xml keep on changing on every save

Thanks

data.title: Getting unexpected results with Label's "percent visible"
data.body:
I'm getting some unexpected results when trying to use a regular Label's "percent visible" property. Whether set through code or through the interface, it doesn't interpret the value correctly. Instead of mapping the visibility to the values 0.00-1.00, it maps it to something more like 0.00-0.80. So at "80%", the label is actually 100% visible. I've posted it on [the forum](http://www.godotengine.org/forum/viewtopic.php?f=11&t=643&sid=afb17797a4ef6e2dafead706c4b129e1) but it appears to be a bug.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Create a label. Give it any text. Length doesn't matter
2. Set the "percent visible" field to 0.0 and note how all the text is invisible, per expectations.
3. Set the field to 0.9 and note how the entire label is visible.

The actual "100%" point seems to lie somewhere around 0.70~0.85 for most tests I've tried. Here's a gif to demonstrate it. Code for linking the parts below.

![mgfwvl](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2746724/3136483/f2d680f0-e842-11e3-8311-ddc3b453985d.gif)

```
var L
var B
var H

func _ready():
    L=get_node("Label")
    B=get_node("Button") #It's a button because I was dicking around when I discovered this
    H=get_node("HSlider")
    set_process(true)

func _process(delta):
    a=H.get_value()/100
    L.set_percent_visible(a)
    B.set_text(str(a))
```

data.title: Colour picker labels are incorrect in HSV and RAW mode
data.body:
When changing the colour picker to HSV mode, the slider labels don't change from RGB to HSV. Also the slider ranges stay at 0-255, when they should be 0-100(%) for S and V and 0-359(degrees) for Hue. This is the way Photoshop and Cinema4D does it, but there are variations on that if you look at Krita or Gimp. Blender just uses a floating point number between 0-1.

As far as I can tell the sliders are doing the correct thing in HSV mode, just a labeling issue.

Same issue when changing to RAW mode.

data.title: [Suggestion] Single quotes in GDScript!
data.body:
``` python
var a = ['one', 'two', 'there\'s an escaped apostrophe in this example!']
```

Just because I can't remember the last time I hardcoded a string in Python using double quotes.
It's not like adjusting my habits for GDScript (which is syntactically inspired by Python) is difficult, but I'm sure other future users would see the value added by this very small addition as well. :)

data.title: refering to a node removed with remove_and_delete_child makes the debugger misbehave
data.body:
code to reproduce:

```
func _ready():
  var button = CheckBox.new()
   add_child(button)
   var button = get_node("CheckButton")
   print (button)
   if button:
      print("yes")
   remove_and_delete_child(button)
   if button:
      print("no")
   print (button)
```

data.title: Joint name in .dae
data.body:
I'm write a tool for create .dae file format.
in `<library_controllers>` node at joint name section I'm do it look like this:

``` XML
<Name_array id="Armature_xxxxx-skin-joints-array" count="4">
    bone00
    bone01
    bone02
    bone03
</Name_array>
```

But it can't import to Godot, to resolve this I must make it like this:

``` XML
<Name_array id="Armature_xxxxx-skin-joints-array" count="4">bone00 bone01 bone02 bone03</Name_array>
```

I must prevent \t\n for resolve it

data.title: CollisionShape2D's attributes aren't animated
data.body: I tried to change the radius and position of a CirculareShape2D within animations in order to match the change of shape of the actor. But if it works well in the animator editor, where I can actually see the collision shape, however in game the collision shape doesn't seem to change at all, both radius and position.

data.title: MeshDataTool crashes on a newly generated surface
data.body:
I was trying to modify a plane I generated using SurfaceTool (to make it larger for instance) and it kinda works, but is very unpredictable. It may crash, or it may just draw one triangle only. Attach it to a meshinstance, add new material using inspector and watch the result. It will show a triangle first time you run it, but if you restart the game - it will crash.

Here's the code:

``` python
extends MeshInstance

export(FixedMaterial) var material = null

func _ready():
    var up = Vector3(0, 1, 0)

    var surface = SurfaceTool.new()
    surface.begin(VisualServer.PRIMITIVE_TRIANGLE_STRIP)

    if(material):
        surface.set_material(material)

    #Generate a surface
    surface.add_vertex(Vector3(1, 0, -1))
    surface.add_uv(Vector2(1, 0))
    surface.add_normal(up)

    surface.add_vertex(Vector3(1, 0, 1))
    surface.add_uv(Vector2(1, 1))
    surface.add_normal(up)

    surface.add_vertex(Vector3(-1, 0, -1))
    surface.add_uv(Vector2(0, 0))
    surface.add_normal(up)

    surface.add_vertex(Vector3(-1, 0, 1))
    surface.add_uv(Vector2(0, 1))
    surface.add_normal(up)

    var mesh = surface.commit()


    #Modify the surface
    var datatool = MeshDataTool.new()
    datatool.create_from_surface(mesh, 0)
    datatool.set_vertex(0, datatool.get_vertex(0) * 10)
    datatool.set_vertex(1, datatool.get_vertex(1) * 10)
    datatool.set_vertex(2, datatool.get_vertex(2) * 10)
    datatool.set_vertex(3, datatool.get_vertex(3) * 10)
    print(datatool.get_vertex_count())

    mesh.surface_remove(0) #Remove the old one
    datatool.commit_to_surface(mesh)

    set_mesh(mesh)
```
